reviewText: [THE OUTSIDE MAN - 1974 - Widescreen presentation - Directed by Jacques Deray] Seeing as how most of the other reviews are for the VHS edition of this flick, or penned by fans of Ann Margret (which I am as well, and fault no one for that), I thought I'd add a few remarks about the new MGM  Limited Edition release currently available.No attempt has been made by the studio to remaster, enhance or improve the print utilized here - it's prefaced with the statement, "This film is presented using the best print available", which isn't all that bad, actually, but in the era of blu ray and remastering, it's not all that great either. The audio is more than adequate for a film from this era, but the video colors range from a bit 'hot' in some of the outdoor scenes, of which there are many, to weak and spotty contrast in certain indoor and night sequences, and an overall flatness to the picture as a whole. Again, this shouldn't turn you away from watching, renting or buying this flick if you've got an interest, but there are no superlatives to encourage you to do any of those things either. But, that said, it is a solid yet anomalous movie with a great cast and a European ending as opposed to a Hollywood conclusion, which made it more attractive to me.The strange thing is, in spite of the excellent cast, no actor really makes the film their own - everyone is good, but no one is given enough screen time to dominate, or is ever established as the true central character or powerful enough to chew up the scenery to make it theirs either. 'Not necessarily a bad thing, but a bit peculiar given the talents involved. Jean-Louis Trintignant would appear the central figure, but his English isn't good enough to warrant giving him a ton of dialogue, as his accent is strong. Americans know him for his role in 'The Conformist' as well as 'And God Created Woman', the film that brought Brigitte Bardot international fame, but he's been in many a formidable French flick through the years. Roy Scheider, in a rare role as a bad guy hit man, has almost no dialogue whatsoever, which is a bit of a waste. Angie Dickenson has a scene in the beginning and one or two at the films conclusion, but is severely underutilized. That leaves Ann Margret, who is captivating in the scenes she's in, both sexy and emotive, but I wish she was in more scenes too. So we have a remarkable cast without anyone being unmistakably remarkable, and I think it has to do with the French writers, directors, cinematographers and additional cast members. Umberto Orsini also has a role on par with the rest of the cast; again unremarkable. Alex Rocco plays the same role he's played his entire life, a bodyguard and muscle enforcer for Orsini, whose presence is felt only at the end of the film.The script is solid, the action firm, it's never dull and concludes nicely for a European crime drama (in spite of the American cast), and is a pleasurable unpolished gem from that era - the other reviewers have already mined the plot, so there's no need for a re-hash from me - I'd recommend this movie to those who appreciate this genre and timeframe without hesitation. Just don't expect an impressive print for a limited release that carries a fairly hefty pricetag. 4 stars.
summary: An Inside View Of 'The Outside Man'...
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Outside Man, 1973 filmThe story begins with an aerial view of Los Angeles. The opening tells of a French production. A taxicab drops off a man at a hotel. A briefcase was left for him. He rents a car. There is a lot of cash and a revolver in the briefcase! He gets a long-distance call from Paris. Victor Kovacs in Beverly Hills is the name. He is expected. But it not Roger Garnier! It's a surprise. Mission accomplished? Roger also gets a surprise at his hotel! A flat tire in the parking lot? How unlucky. Hide and seek in an underground garage. Can he get away? And find a refuge? The phone call from Paris rings [no subtitles]. The elevator arrives to take him down. "Which way is down town?" Roger picks up a hitchhiker who knows the way. Really? One addiction for another? Roger takes an exit and leaves the car behind.Police cars tell of a raid on a place. He gets a message to meet a contact, he needs papers to travel. The police find that white car with its contents. TV has the news. Eric now has a police escort to school. A man visits Mrs. Barnes, then that woman. Will she take him to Lucien? Can he get away? We see scenes of the streets near the sea. [Venice?] Shots fired! The police arrive with their cars. There is a car chase for action. We see a roller skating derby. A good place for a clandestine meeting. But the hunter finds his prey. We learn who was behind the murder! Lucien has second thoughts. "What about me?" Lucien explains at a motel. There is a clue in the description of the killer! Lucien followed Mrs. Kovacs and left a clue to be followed. There is a surprise! They talk. "You're the proof." Lucien explains what they must do. There is an expected surprise! "He's the other one" says Mrs. Barnes. The police act on this clue and talk to Alex. He knows nothing about the Frenchman. Dumping the body sent a message.The police suspect an inside job. That could start a gang war if they suspected Alex! Lucien needed money for his gambling debts. Two men fly in from Paris, friends of Lucien. There is a wake for Victor. One man has a floral tribute. An unusual setting? Mourners arrive to view the Loved One. [No prayers.] There is a shot, then more. Bodies fall, like some pagan funereal games. "I'm the boss now." "You never saw me." The police sirens mark the end of this drama. Men flee across the green lawn. That hearse is parked now. Lucien sits and waits. The credits name the actors.This story seems to be inspired by Graham Greene's novel "A Gun For Hire". This was adapted for an American movie in 1942 "This Gun For Hire". The story about killing an assassin to cover up the crime seems to explain the events of November 1963. Art imitates life. This is a good drama as long as you accept the story and don't question the details. You can compare it to the other movies of 1972. Wouldn't this story be different if made entirely in Hollywood?

reviewText: The cooperative European/American production THE OUTSIDE MAN is a polished yet offbeat action/crime film. For Ann-Margret and Angie Dickenson fans, it will be a trip down Mammary Lane.It's the story of a suave hitman (Trintignant) who's imported from France to assassinate a top echelon mobster. Lucien Bellon goes to the man's L.A. estate and shoots his victim at point blank range. Later, Bellon sees a TV news story about the murder and begins to wonder why the killer is described as a tall, young American clad in corduroys. When another hitman (Scheider) tries to shoot Bellon, he concludes that he and his stalker were hired by whoever wanted the mobster dead, and that both of them would be murdered, as well. Rather than return to Paris and certain death, Bellon decides to stay in L.A. to unravel the mystery. But first he must find a way to enlist the aid of the man hired to kill him.During his American visit, Bellon has difficulty comprehending such colloquialisms as "make a 'U'," "bread" and "scratch." He also hijacks a car driven by Georgia Engel (sweet young Georgette on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show") and holds her and her son hostage in their own home for a few hours. The handsome Trintignant is an absolute star while Scheider is interesting as Bellon's pursuer-- he moves the story along well. Ann-Margret's "assets" practically fall out of her floozyish outfits, and Angie Dickenson has little to do here. (Watch for Talia Shire's "make-up girl" cameo.)As of 1/09, THE OUTSIDE MAN was not available on DVD.Jean-Louis Trintignant primarily appeared in European movies. He did however have a small part in UNDER FIRE (1983), which starred Nick Nolte, Ed Harris and Gene Hackman.  (VHS edition)  (DVD edition)Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 viewer poll rating found at a film resource website.(6.2) The Outside Man (Italy/France/USA-1972) - Jean-Louis Trintignant/Ann-Margret/Roy Scheider/Angie Dickinson/Georgia Engel/Michel Constantin/Ted de Corsia/Talia Shire

reviewText: This is a hit-man intrigue that stars mostly French actors with Roy Scheider as a quiet secondary hit man.  The story is not very compelling, although it could have been.  Still, if you are a 70s films fan, this is one for your list.
summary: Vintage Roy Schieder but not really

reviewText: The film is confusing only because the lead actor is French and his heavy accent when he does speak left me mostly in the dark because of my lack of understanding what he was saying.  On the other hand Roy Scheider plays a mostly silent but deadly killer well and the eye candy combo of Ann-Margret and Angie Dickinson kept my attention not only with their looks but with their acting.

reviewText: I saw this month in 1974 or 75 and have wanted to watch it again for many years.  I had forgotten some of the details but remembered the basic plot so there were no surprises.  In 1974, the movie had a number of novel plot twists and was, for the time, graphically violent.  Today, the violence would shock very few.  What is shocking is how a film with no explosions and limited action but with a plot is so much better than most of the junk being produced today.The visual quality of the CD was much better than I expected.  I thought the price was exorbitant but I bought it from Amazon because I have prime shipping.  I would recommend this movie to those individuals who like crime movies and movies about hit men.  Movies like Heat (the Al Pacino movie), The Limey, Blood Simple, Johnny Handsome, and Killing them Softly.  If you are looking for explosions and non-stop action then I would not recommend it.  In terms of quality, I would rate it as being in the same league as Johnny Handsome.  A good but not a great film.It is noir but it does have an existential twist.  Perhaps all noir is existential?  I would love to see a re-make if it were done with some taste and without becoming an exercise in mindless violence.

reviewText: A French assassin (Jean Louis Trintignant) is imported to Los Angeles to make a hit on a wealthy businessman (Ted De Corsia) with ties to the mob. But after he carries out the hit, suddenly he finds himself hunted by another mysterious hit man (Roy Scheider) while the businessman's widow (Angie Dickinson) gives the police a description of her husband's murderer that is the opposite of Trintignant. Directed by Jacques Deray (BORSALINO) who co-wrote the screenplay with Jean Claude Carriere (DISCREET CHARM OF THE BOURGEOISIE), the film could well have been entitled A FRENCHMAN IN L.A.. Trintignant's professional assassin finds himself adrift in a foreign landscape with an unfamiliar culture and terrain. Deray covers L.A. from the Beverly Hills mansions to the seedy downtown L.A. to the Venice beaches, plush valet parking department stores for wealthy wives to strip clubs and imbues them an unsettling alien aura. Unfortunately, the film begins to fall apart at the very end but Deray's downbeat noir ending is uncompromised. The obtrusive score is by Michel Legrand. With Ann-Margret doing her bruised vulnerability act as Trintignant's L.A. contact, Jackie Earle Haley, Umberto Orsini, Alex Rocco, Ben Piazza, John Hillerman and in a rare dramatic role, Georgia Engel (THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW).The MGM MOD DVD-r is a good looking anamorphic wide screen (1.85) transfer.
summary: Stylish L.A. noir through the eyes of a Frenchman
Title: N/A
